citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility failed to properly implement their mechanism of direct communication, regarding several concerning daily
observations, to the attending veterinarian:
•The elderly black leopard was observed to be very weak and unsteady on its hind limbs. As it struggled to cross a small
log on the ground, it was seen stumbling and falling against the enclosure.
•A cockatoo was observed with an overgrown lower beak. The overgrowth was approximately 3 inches in length and
curved to the right side of the upper beak, impacting the way it ate and grasped the side of its enclosure as it climbed.
•A scarlet macaw had no feathers visible on both sides of its face.
•A green amazon parrot had a line of feather loss extending above its right eye, crossing the top of its head and
connecting to the top of its left eye.
When asked if she had discussed these findings with her attending veterinarian, she stated that she had not.
Failure to observe and communicate animal health issues to the attending veterinarian can lead to unnecessary pain,
suffering, or even death of the animals.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include a mechanism of direct and
frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is
conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by today, April 15, 2024.

The facility failed to maintain several bird enclosures in good repair.
• The enclosure housing two blue and yellow macaws had a metal pipe extending across the middle of the cage that the
birds use as one of their perches. The ends of the pipe were covered in dusty, flaking rust. The metal door to the
enclosure had flaking paint and rust over most of its surface, and a hanging, blue plastic barrel, used for shelter, was
heavily chewed on and damaged.
• The enclosure housing a scarlet macaw had a rusty chain and a heavily chewed and damaged, hanging blue plastic
barrel.
• The enclosure housing 2 sun conures had walls constructed of rusty wire, rusty fixtures, and numerous areas of chewed
and damaged wood along its roof and platforms.
Failure to maintain these enclosures in good repair could lead to injury of the birds or compromise the integrity of the
enclosure which could allow escape.
Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in contact with birds must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural
integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning. To be corrected by May 6, 2024.

A white and blue ceramic bowl in the blue and yellow macaw enclosure had a layer of dirt and grime on the inside walls
and bottom of the bowl. This bowl is used to hold food offered to the birds.
Failure to maintain clean food receptacles can attract pests and create an insanitary condition which may contaminate the
food within and lead to harm or disease to the birds.
Food receptacles and feeding areas must be kept clean and sanitized. Food receptacles must be made of a durable
material that can be easily cleaned and sanitized or be replaced when worn or soiled. To be corrected by today, April 15,
2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility failed to properly implement their mechanism of direct communication, regarding several concerning daily 
observations, to the attending veterinarian: 
 
•The elderly black leopard was observed to be very weak and unsteady on its hind limbs. As it struggled to cross a small 
log on the ground, it was seen stumbling and falling against the enclosure. 
•A cockatoo was observed with an overgrown lower beak. The overgrowth was approximately 3 inches in length and 
curved to the right side of the upper beak, impacting the way it ate and grasped the side of its enclosure as it climbed.  
•A scarlet macaw had no feathers visible on both sides of its face. 
•A green amazon parrot had a line of feather loss extending above its right eye, crossing the top of its head and 
connecting to the top of its left eye. 
 
When asked if she had discussed these findings with her attending veterinarian, she stated that she had not. 
 
Failure to observe and communicate animal health issues to the attending veterinarian can lead to unnecessary pain, 
suffering, or even death of the animals. 
 
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include a mechanism of direct and 
frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is 
conveyed to the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by today, April 15, 2024. 
3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility failed to maintain several bird enclosures in good repair. 
 
• The enclosure housing two blue and yellow macaws had a metal pipe extending across the middle of the cage that the 
birds use as one of their perches. The ends of the pipe were covered in dusty, flaking rust. The metal door to the 
enclosure had flaking paint and rust over most of its surface, and a hanging, blue plastic barrel, used for shelter, was 
heavily chewed on and damaged.

• The enclosure housing a scarlet macaw had a rusty chain and a heavily chewed and damaged, hanging blue plastic 
barrel. 
• The enclosure housing 2 sun conures had walls constructed of rusty wire, rusty fixtures, and numerous areas of chewed 
and damaged wood along its roof and platforms. 
 
Failure to maintain these enclosures in good repair could lead to injury of the birds or compromise the integrity of the 
enclosure which could allow escape. 
 
Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in contact with birds must be free of rust or damage that affects the structural 
integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning. To be corrected by May 6, 2024. 
3.155(b) 
   
Feeding 
A white and blue ceramic bowl in the blue and yellow macaw enclosure had a layer of dirt and grime on the inside walls 
and bottom of the bowl. This bowl is used to hold food offered to the birds. 
 
Failure to maintain clean food receptacles can attract pests and create an insanitary condition which may contaminate the 
food within and lead to harm or disease to the birds. 
 
Food receptacles and feeding areas must be kept clean and sanitized. Food receptacles must be made of a durable 
material that can be easily cleaned and sanitized or be replaced when worn or soiled. To be corrected by today, April 15, 
2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
